issueDTO.title: Raise error when GRD file is corrupted
issueDTO.description:
**Description of the desired feature:**

In case the GRD file that is intended to be read is corrupted and there are missing elements in the grid, our `hm.load_oasis_montaj_grid` function will fail, raising an error complaining about not being able to reshape the grid to the expected shape.

We could improve the user interface by checking if the number of elements in the read 1d array matches the expected shape and raise an error with an informative error message if it doesn't. It could be a `ValueError` with a message like: 

```python
f"Encountered grid with {n} elements that doesn't match the expected shape ({shape}). The '{filename}' file is possibly corrupted."
```

The idea for this new feature was triggered after a conversation with @marcoutojr


**Are you willing to help implement and maintain this feature?** 

Yes, sure! Although I'd love to see someone else tackling this issue.
comments: Good catch! Nice to see @marcoutojr here 🥳

I???ve just pushed this PR,  Sorry for the delay I got caught up with another project and it slipped my mind for a bit.

This change is ready for review, I???ve kept it simple and tested it manually with a fake .grd file to confirm the new check works as expected.

Looking forward to your feedback/suggestion, happy to tweak anything if needed!

issueDTO.title: Add SSMRunCommandOperator
issueDTO.description:
### Description

Amazon Systems Manager (SSM) is used by system admins to manage AWS resources like EC2. It also provided ability for companies to run scripts on the EC2 machines securely using it's RunCommand feature. Adding SSM RunCommand Operator to the Amazon provider package will unlock migration to Airflow from legacy job scheduling frameworks like AutoSys

### Use case/motivation

I work with a few customers that are in the process of migrating jobs from AutoSys and other legacy frameworks to Airflow. For these customers, a lot of their existing jobs are in shell scripts running on EC2. When they migrate to Airflow, they are looking for an easy way to lift those scripts and run on Airflow. SSHOperator could be an option for this but in many corporate environments, SSH is disabled for security reasons. One of the secure ways AWS recommends executing a remote script on EC2 is by using SSM RunCommand.

### Related issues

_No response_

### Are you willing to submit a PR?

- [ ] Yes I am willing to submit a PR!

### Code of Conduct

- [X] I agree to follow this project's [Code of Conduct](https://github.com/apache/airflow/blob/main/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md)

issueDTO.title: Consolidate dispatch release workflows into one
issueDTO.description:
## Description

There's multiple dispatch release workflows for various Camunda versions, e.g.:

- https://github.com/camunda/camunda/blob/main/.github/workflows/dispatch-release-8-3.yaml
- https://github.com/camunda/camunda/blob/main/.github/workflows/dispatch-release-8-4.yaml
- https://github.com/camunda/camunda/blob/main/.github/workflows/dispatch-release-8-5.yaml
- https://github.com/camunda/camunda/blob/main/.github/workflows/dispatch-release-8-6.yaml
- https://github.com/camunda/camunda/blob/main/.github/workflows/dispatch-release-8-7.yaml
- https://github.com/camunda/camunda/blob/main/.github/workflows/dispatch-release-8-8.yaml

With the minor difference of what branch's release workflow it's using, e.g.:

https://github.com/camunda/camunda/blob/main/.github/workflows/dispatch-release-8-6.yaml#L13

```
    uses: camunda/camunda/.github/workflows/camunda-platform-release.yml@stable/8.6
```

### Acceptance criteria

- Replace the dispatch workflow with a single workflow `dispatch-release.yaml` that supports `repository_dispatch` events in a way, that it can work for all Camunda 8 versions.
- Replace all usages/references to the old workflows in the release process.
  - for example: https://github.com/camunda/zeebe-engineering-processes/blob/main/src/main/resources/release/forms/post_release_update_dry_stable_release_workflow.form#L20 (but search for more if any)
comments: example of triggering of the workflows from C8: https://bru-2.operate.camunda.io/689a796f-7efa-487f-9e44-76ca3a98c77b/operate/processes/2251799937878192

As discussed [here](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1PYOMGEW5vcIhgDBY_BIe62s4sE26C2EbDqjgSM30URE/edit?tab=t.31uot4tf151e) this task should fix the misleading link found in the `run_release_prepare_release` form.

@maxdanilov @liliancavalet We could also stop using `repository_dispatch` events entirely and switch to using [GH REST API workflow dispatch call](https://docs.github.com/en/rest/actions/workflows?apiVersion=2022-11-28#create-a-workflow-dispatch-event) like we do in other parts of the release process:

* e.g. to trigger the Identity version update GHA we call `https://api.github.com/repos/camunda/camunda/actions/workflows/update-identity.yml/dispatches` with `{"ref": "main", "inputs": { ... }}`, or to trigger Zeebe Process Test builds
* more consistent and aligned that way, no special one-off solution in the monorepo

This way also allows specifying a target branch directly, making it unnecessary to dispatch from the `main` branch: call `https://api.github.com/repos/camunda/camunda/actions/workflows/camunda-platform-release.yml/dispatches` with e.g. `{"ref": "stable/8.7", "inputs": { ... }}` etc.

We'd only need one `camunda-platform-release.yml` file on each stable branch and main which can be invoked externally, no additional logic is needed on main. WDYT?

@liliancavalet, as @cmur2 pointed, once those changes are merged please update the [release implementation docs](https://github.com/camunda/camunda/wiki/Release-Process#implementation) with the dispatch mechanism change.

summary.main: Consolidate multiple dispatch release workflows into one, replacing old workflows and references in the release process, and making the process more consistent and aligned.

summary.attemptedFixes: The issue mentions discussions about using GH REST API workflow dispatch call, and a suggestion to stop using repository_dispatch events entirely. It also mentions the need to update the release implementation docs with the dispatch mechanism change.
summary.otherNotes: The issue aims to consolidate multiple dispatch release workflows into one, replacing old workflows and references in the release process. The new workflow will support repository_dispatch events and work for all Camunda 8 versions. It also proposes using GH REST API workflow dispatch call instead of repository_dispatch events, making the process more consistent and aligned.

issueDTO.title: When copying and pasting an entry to another bib file - all attached files should also be copied
issueDTO.description:
As user, I have my `personal.bib` and a collaboratively edited `paper.bib` (Refs https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/issues/160). The `paper.bib` has configured a (separate) file directory where the PDFs are stored. If this is true, I would like to have to following behavior:

1. I copy an entry of `personal.bib`. That entry has attached a PDF `A.pdf`.
2. I paste that entry to `paper.bib`.
3. `A.pdf` should be copied to the file directory of library `paper.bib`

In summary: All attached files should be copied if original files are not reachable from new library. One needs to keep the relative path structure while copying (to keep the files field unmodified)

Hi.
I'd like to give this a try. It seems like no one is actively working on it right now, so I'm happy to explore the codebase and see if I can implement the file-copy behavior as described.

I'm new to JabRef.

I tried the following structure:
.
????????? paper
??????? ????????? paper.bib
????????? personal
    ????????? personal.bib
    ????????? something.txt

personal.bib has a file field pointing to something.txt. When I copy the entry from personal.bib into paper.bib, I can still see the attachment in the GUI, but trying to open it from within paper.bib fails.

Just to confirm: In this case, the file something.txt should be copied to the paper directory so that it becomes reachable relative to paper.bib, right?

@umu directory structure a bit strange. But OK. I am one the road. Short answer: seems right. Please keep the relative path; but the file has to be copied (because the starting point changes). Read on at https://devdocs.jabref.org/code-howtos/#get-a-relative-filename-or-path-for-a-file and think of different cases. Maybe the file is reachable from the other bib file without copying; then just the path needs to be adapted.

Sorry for asking again, I just want to make sure I fully understand the intended behavior. Let???s say I have the following structure: When I copy an entry from personal.bib to parent.bib, then the file is not reachable and needs to be copied, that part is clear. But if I copy an entry from personal.bib to paper.bib, and paper.bib has @ Comment{jabref-meta: fileDirectory:paperfiles;}, the file is still reachable without copying. However, the current implementation keeps the file field as: file = {:personalfiles/something.txt:TXT} And you would like that to be changed to a relative path like: file = {:../personalfiles/something.txt:TXT} So that it works correctly from the perspective of paper.bib with its fileDirectory set to paperfiles/? Thanks again for your guidance and for your time!

> Let???s say I have the following structure:

Note that this structure is strange, because the "bibs" folder is a sub folder of the directory containing the `parent.bib`.

You also need to say HOW the directories are configured for each `.bib` file.

I assume you have `.` configured as directory for each.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/8d8aa826-daac-4ad8-bf20-e03155e046f8)

> When I copy an entry from personal.bib to parent.bib, then the file is not reachable and needs to be copied, that part is clear.

Case 1: Directory reachable.

- File path in personal.bib: `personalfiles/something.txt`
- File path in parent.bib: `bibs/personalfiles/something.txt`

Only path needs to be adapted. From the first to the second.

Case 2: Directory not reachable

- Assume that `personal.bib` has `personalfiles` configured as file directory.
- Assume that `parent.bib` has configured `parentfiles` as file directory.

Then, the relative path is `something.txt` for `personal.bib` - and also for `parent.bib`. Thus no need to adapt anything.

Case 3: Directory not reachable and relative paths differ

- Assume that `personal.bib` has `.` configured as file directory.
- Assume that `parent.bib` has configured `parentfiles` as file directory.

Then, the relative path is `something.txt` for `personal.bib`. It should be `personalfiles/something.txt` for `parant.bib` AND `./parerntfiles/personalfiles`  be created as directory - to keep the nested directory structure. 

> But if I copy an entry from personal.bib to paper.bib, and paper.bib has @ Comment{jabref-meta: fileDirectory:paperfiles;}, the file is still reachable without copying.

Then, your assumption is that `parent.bib` has `bibs/paperfiles` configured and `personal.bib`, `paperfiles`. Then the relative paths starting from that are the same for both.

In case BOTH have `paperfiles` configured, the first path is `./paperfiles`, the second one is `bibs/paperfiels`. But they are DIFFERENT (see the `bib` included in the second). And this is case 1.

> However, the current implementation keeps the file field as:
> 
> file = {:personalfiles/something.txt:TXT}
> 
> And you would like that to be changed to a relative path like:
> 
> file = {:../personalfiles/something.txt:TXT}

In case the directory is "reachable" (based on the directory configuration). If the file is non-reachable, it needs to be copied. Case 3.

You need to document this. Create a file `files.md` in https://github.com/JabRef/jabref/tree/main/docs/requirements. Follow the guidance at `index.md` there how to do.
Thank you for the detailed explanation! I???ll try to implement and document it over the weekend.

issueDTO.title: tree-sitter-nim inclusion
issueDTO.description:
I recently stumbled upon aider and read that it "...relies on tree-sitter-language-pack to provide pre-packaged versions of tree-sitter language parsers." Unfortunately, a tree-sitter-nim hasn't been included yet.

I found [a forum topic](https://forum.nim-lang.org/t/10214) that linked to three different github repos:

- https://github.com/alaviss/tree-sitter-nim ([some discussion](https://github.com/tree-sitter/tree-sitter/discussions/2248))
- https://github.com/aMOPel/tree-sitter-nim
- https://github.com/paranim/tree-sitter-nim

Can any of these be included? Would the authors of these need to be involved? I'm fairly clueless on this topic, so I'm just hoping for some pointers on what it would take to get this done.
comments:
Hi there. 

This package is not affiliated with Aider, although Aider relies on it. 

Anyhow, a PR adding NIM Grammer is welcome. 

It looks like just one of these repos is maintained. Id suggest you try adding this one. Contributions welcome.
@alaviss Do you think your tree-sitter-nim is ready for inclusion in this pack? And are you willing to make that happen?

I'm not quite sure what constitutes "ready" in this case, but the parser is quite stable and has been a part of nvim-treesitter, helix editor and zed editor for awhile now.

I will not partake in adding the parser to this repository myself, so either you or someone else would have to do it. However, should there be difficulties in building or using the parser, you can open an issue and I would be happy to assist.

Check that nim is installable using cargo please.

issueDTO.title: Potential issue with AWS Textract integration not retrieving full content
issueDTO.description:
## Description

When using Medplum's AWS Textract integration to extract text from PDF documents, the API response contains a `NextToken` field. This token indicates that the response is paginated and that additional results are available. However, it appears that the current Medplum integration does not utilize the `NextToken` to fetch the next set of results, which causes incomplete text extraction when the document is large.

I noticed that the [loadAwsConfig](https://github.com/medplum/medplum/blob/main/packages/server/src/cloud/aws/config.ts#L13) function references the `NextToken`, so I would like to confirm whether this behavior is due to a misconfiguration on my end. I tested the integration using the AWS Textract action available in the Medplum app (app.medplum.com) as well as with the [textract demo bot](https://github.com/medplum/medplum/blob/main/examples/medplum-demo-bots/src/textract-bot.ts), and encountered the same issue in both cases.

## Steps to Reproduce

1. Go to https://app.medplum.com/Media/new
2. Upload a PDF with many pages
3. Go to its detail page
4. Click on the `AWS Textract` action to process the PDF
5. Once the extraction is complete, open the detail page of the resulting `Media` resource
6. Check that the `content` only contains text from the first page of the PDF, and also check for the presence of the `NextToken` attribute indicating more pages of text are available

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/bc6876a1-0b3b-468f-9d7b-e5c8dfa650a5)

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/189b43ae-5feb-4775-b62e-9c5d47adbab6)

i can understand that the cureent AWS textextract can only process first page of the multipage pdf because it is not properly handlling 'NextToken' for pagingation.The NextToken indicates that there are more subsequent pages that are needed to be fetched but it doest get fetched

**My Approach to this code**
First i will understand the current implementation that will be done by understanding and reveiwing the necessary textextract code 
Identify the part where the pagination logic should be added (mostly in GetDocumentAnaluysis )
My take would be to implemennt a recursive ,if not an itterative logic to fetch all necessary pages by updating nexttoken 
Then i will test with some multipage pdf to make sure it works as intended 

**some question from me**
is there any coding standards or pattern shoudl i folllow in the medplum code base?
is there any prefered coding standard for combining the resultls of multipage pdf ?

Thank you for you guildance 

Also i am a new to opensouce and eager to learn so if any tips to improve please let me know 

@pamella I'd love your feedback on this approach when you have a moment. Since this issue hasn't had activity in a while, I wanted to check in before starting. Thank you!

issueDTO.title: Improve our test coverage
issueDTO.description:
### Feature description

Many of our existing algorithm files have little to no unit testing. This is problematic because this can easily let bugs slip through. We want some assurance that the code we currently have is correct and functional. We welcome all contributors to open PRs to help us add tests to our codebase.

### How to find low-coverage files

Go to the Actions tab in this repository and find the most recent **build** workflow run. Open the logs under "Run Tests" and scroll down until you find the section on code coverage:
```
---------- coverage: platform linux, python 3.12.0-final-0 -----------
Name                                                                          Stmts   Miss  Cover   Missing
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
quantum/q_fourier_transform.py                                                   30     30     0%   14-93
scripts/validate_solutions.py                                                    54     54     0%   2-94
strings/min_cost_string_conversion.py                                            78     75     4%   20-57, 61-75, 79-129
...
```
The "Cover" column tells you what percentage of the lines in that file are covered by tests. We want to increase this percentage for existing files. Find a file with low coverage percentage that you wish to write tests for, add doctests for each function, and open a PR with your changes. You do not need to have a perfect coverage percentage, but all functions should have doctests.

Some files will naturally be hard to write tests for. For example, the file may be poorly written because they lack any functions. Other files might be how-tos, meaning they simply demonstrate how to use an existing library's functions rather than implementing the algorithm themselves. Ignore these kinds of files, as they will need to be rewritten eventually. Furthermore, ignore files in the `web_programming` and `project_euler` directories. Web programming files are inherently hard to test and Project Euler files have their own validation workflow, so don't worry about their test coverage.

_**When you open your PR, put "Contributes to #9943" in the PR description.**_ Do not use the word "fixes", "resolves", or "closes". This issue is an ongoing one, and your PR will not single-handedly resolve this issue.

### How to add doctests

A doctest is a unit test that is contained within the documentation comment (docstring) for a function. Here is an example of what doctests look like within a docstring:
```py
def add(a: int, b: int) -> int:
    """
    Adds two non-negative numbers.
    >>> add(1, 1)
    2
    >>> add(2, 5)
    7
    >>> add(1, 0)
    1
    >>> add(-1, -1)
    Traceback (most recent last):
    ...
    ValueError: Numbers must be non-negative
    """
```
For every function in the file you choose, you should write doctests like the ones shown above in its docstring. If a function doesn't have a docstring, add one. Your doctests should be comprehensive but not excessive: you should write just enough tests to cover all basic cases as well as all edge cases (e.g., negative numbers, empty lists, etc).

Do not simply run a function on some example inputs and put its output as the expected output for a doctest. This assumes that the function is implemented correctly when it might not be. Verify independently that your doctests and their expected outputs are correct. **Your PR will not be merged if it has failing tests.** If you happen to discover a bug while writing doctests, please fix it.

_**Please read our [contributing guidelines](https://github.com/TheAlgorithms/Python/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md) before you contribute.**_

> How is the percentage determined? The tests I added only bumped the coverage by 1%

@RaymondDashWu The coverage percentage is calculated from the total number of lines covered by tests across _all_ files in the repo. As of writing, the latest builds show the following:
```
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
TOTAL                                                                         31846   9986    69%
```
There are 9986 lines of code in total _not_ covered by tests compared to 31846 lines of code in total, which is how the 69% comes about. The tests that you added only improved the coverage for _one_ file out of the hundreds of files that we have, and that's why it barely changed the percentage at all.

This is why I said in my previous comment that this is an _ongoing_ issue. No single PR will improve our coverage enough to "fix" this issue.

issueDTO.title: SafeCoT: Monitoring and Ensuring Chain-of-Thought Faithfulness in Inference-Time Compute
issueDTO.description:
# Problem

The emergence of the **inference-time compute paradigm** presents a critical safety challenge: ensuring **chain-of-thought (CoT) faithfulness**. Through our work on **OptiLLM**, an open-source inference optimization framework implementing over 15 state-of-the-art techniques (MCTS, Chain-of-Thought, Mixture of Agents, etc.), we've identified three interconnected risks in reasoning models:

1. **Unfaithful reasoning chains**: Reasoning becomes unfaithful to the model's actual decision process, creating a false impression of safety while masking problematic reasoning.
2. **Monitoring degradation**: As reasoning complexity increases, transparency decreases, weakening monitoring mechanisms.
3. **Unsafe exploration**: During reasoning, models may "think" about harmful content even when final outputs appear safe.

These challenges are particularly dangerous because they undermine our ability to verify safety properties and apply safeguards in frontier models. Recent research confirms that even leading reasoning models can exhibit significant unfaithfulness in complex reasoning tasks [1,2].

# Approach

We propose **SafeCoT**, a comprehensive framework to **measure, monitor, and ensure chain-of-thought faithfulness**. Our approach leverages our expertise in inference-time optimization to:

- Create a **taxonomy of faithfulness failures** across diverse reasoning models and tasks
- Develop **quantitative faithfulness metrics** tailored to various inference-time techniques
- Implement **real-time monitoring systems** to detect faithfulness violations during inference
- Design **intervention mechanisms** to address safety risks when faithfulness violations are detected
- Build a **benchmarking suite** to evaluate the correlation between CoT faithfulness and downstream safety outcomes

We will leverage **OptiLLM's inference proxy architecture** to integrate monitoring capabilities with any reasoning model via their APIs, ensuring broad applicability across the AI ecosystem.

# Impact

This project will deliver:

- An **open-source toolkit** for evaluating CoT faithfulness across reasoning models
- **Empirical evidence** on how faithfulness correlates with safety across inference techniques
- **Practical monitoring strategies** for inference-time compute, ready for integration into existing systems
- **Adaptive intervention mechanisms** to mitigate unsafe reasoning behaviors

By systematically addressing CoT faithfulness, we aim to provide the AI safety community with both a **deeper scientific understanding** of this critical challenge and **practical tools** to enhance safety in the inference-time compute paradigm.

# References

1. Guo, Y., Wang, Z., Yang, Q., et al. (2025). *"Flash Thinking: Optimizing Chain-of-Thought Reasoning with Supervised Reinforcement Learning."*
2. Snell, J., Reid, M., Tian, F., et al. (2024). *"Towards Trustworthy Chain-of-Thought Reasoning Through Faithfulness."*
comments:
Reinforcement Learning with Verifiable Rewards Implicitly Incentivizes Correct Reasoning in Base LLMs
 https://arxiv.org/abs/2506.14245 proposes CoT-Pass@K which mandates that both the reasoning path and the final answer be correct. This can be used to check the faithfulness of CoTs for math problems and determine conditions under which models deviate.
Also see - https://github.com/jettjaniak/chainscope
A good practical example of unfaithfulness in cot - https://www.lesswrong.com/posts/me7wFrkEtMbkzXGJt/race-and-gender-bias-as-an-example-of-unfaithful-chain-of

repository.description: Optimizing inference proxy for LLMs
repository.name: optillm

It's about creating a taxonomy of faithfulness failures, developing quantitative faithfulness metrics, implementing real-time monitoring systems, designing intervention mechanisms, and building a benchmarking suite.

issueDTO.title: Stories for components
issueDTO.description:
Each of the components inside Headlamp need [stories](https://storybook.js.org/) made for the different states.

- for easier manual UI testing, where the components are separate from the backend and each other.
- for automated regression testing of the presentational parts of the components

## Components that need stories

There's a number of components that still don't have any stories written for them.

Please write in the issue if you want to start on one, and then tick it off here when it's merged in.

- [ ] common/ReleaseNotes
- [x] components/App/Notifications
- [ ] components/App/Layout
- [ ] components/App/AppContainer
- [x] components/cluster/Charts
- [x] components/cluster/Chooser
- [x] components/cluster/ClusterChooser
- [ ] components/cluster/Overview

## Components that need stories improving

Some stories test only one possible state. These stories need improving.

How can you find these ones that need more states?

If you run make frontend-test from the root of the repo you'll see it prints out some code coverage.
`cd frontend && npm run test -- --coverage`

From that you could see if there's any more major code paths that might need covering with more story states.
(There's a html report in coverage/index.html as well with more details)


## Where should the stories go?

A good example to look at is `src/components/common/ActionButton`.

The preferred layout is the folder layout like this:

```
Component/Component.tsx, main place where the component goes. Named after the component.
Component/index.tsx, This should export things from Component.tsx
Component/Component.stories.tsx, contains the component shown in different states.
Component/__snapshots__ , where the story shot files are.
```

## Presentational VS container (logic) components

See [documentation here](link-to-story-js). In short, the logic should be separated so mainly the component can be tested without dependencies on other things. An example of logic that could be separated is API calls.

Some refactoring is probably needed to implement stories:

- to place components in a folder, with filenames the same name as the component
- to separate the presentational "pure" parts

## viewing the stories, and running the tests

To view the storybook:

```bash
cd frontend
npm install
npm run storybook
```

To run the tests, and generate the snapshot files (rendered html):

```bash
cd frontend
npm install # not needed if you've done it already.
npm run test -- --coverage
```

You can also run the tests without the interactive test runner like this:
```bash
CI=true npm run test -- --coverage
```

issueDTO.title: [CLI] Cannot type during actions (unlike other AI tools)
issueDTO.description:
## Problem
Users cannot type or provide input while the agent is executing actions, unlike other AI tools (e.g., Claude) where users can interrupt or provide guidance during execution.

## Current Behavior
- When agent is running, input is blocked
- Users must use Ctrl-P to pause, then provide input
- No way to provide real-time guidance or corrections

## Expected Behavior
- Allow users to type during action execution
- Provide immediate feedback or corrections
- Similar UX to Claude and other AI tools where users can interrupt naturally

## User Experience Impact
- **Frustration**: Cannot provide immediate feedback
- **Workflow interruption**: Must pause, then speak, then resume
- **Missed opportunities**: Cannot guide the agent in real-time

## Current Workaround
Users must:
1. Press Ctrl-P to pause
2. Wait for pause confirmation
3. Type their message
4. Use `/resume` to continue

## Proposed Solution
1. **Concurrent input**: Allow input during action execution
2. **Smart interruption**: Automatically pause when user starts typing
3. **Queue management**: Handle user input appropriately during execution

## Technical Context
The issue is in the input handling during agent execution. The `process_agent_pause()` function only listens for specific key combinations, and the main input loop is blocked during execution.

## Related Files
- `openhands/cli/tui.py` (process_agent_pause function, read_prompt_input)
- `openhands/cli/main.py` (event handling and input management)

## Comparison
- **Claude**: Users can type anytime and the system handles interruption gracefully
- **OpenHands CLI**: Requires explicit pause before input

issueDTO.title: Naming/PredicateMethod: more detailed introspection of the method body
issueDTO.description:
## Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.

One more idea/suggestion about Naming/PredicateName after trying to apply it to a large codebase. There is one widespread pattern that triggers the cop which feels "wrong":

```ruby
def do_something
  return false unless should_be_done?

  internal_do_something

  true
end
```

I.e., the main thing about the method is side effects, but it also returns booleans indicating whether it has invoked something or not. It shouldn't be named like a predicate, but the cop will suggest so.

## Describe the solution you'd like

How can we filter out those methods? It is not very simple but pretty straightforward:
* starting from each return value
* go back through statements in the method body
* ...and check if this statement assigns some value used to calculate the return value; if not, it is not a predicate.

E.g., this is not a predicate:
```ruby
def foo
  File.write('test.log', some_data) # this doesn't participate in result

  true
end
```
...and this is a predicate:
```ruby
def foo
  data = File.read('test.log', some_data) # this is used to calculate the next line
  line = data.find { it.include?('ERROR:') } # this is used to calculate value used for result

  line.match?('not found') # start analysis from here
end
```

It will still miss edge cases like this (side effect is present, but doesn't look like it
```ruby
def foo
  some_complicated_side_effect(lot, of, params) == :success
end
```
...but so will the human, so `rubocop:disable` in this case + appropriate comment would be helpful :)
comments:
Hello,

this looks like the false positive we were facing at #14232

>  the main thing about the method is side effects, 

Since the method has side effects, it should end with a `!` and probably this cop should ignore bang methods
I was thinking it'd be better to have this as some configuration option.

Is this prevalent and diverse enough that using `AllowedMethods`/`AllowedPatterns` won't work for your use case? In my experience a lot of these sort of methods are named `call`, for instance, which is added to `AllowedMethods` by default. If you follow a similar pattern, there could be a simpler solution.

Otherwise, my concern is that this would overly complicate the cop. It would essentially mean that any method that returns a literal boolean where it isn't the only statement would be considered to not be a predicate, because there is work being done that isn't considered in the return value.

> ```ruby
> def foo
>  some_complicated_side_effect(lot, of, params) == :success
> end
> ```

I don't see why this shouldn't be a predicate method, since it's returning a pretty straightforward check (does the complicated method return `:success`, the side effects in the method are not relevant IMO).

> Since the method has side effects, it should end with a `!` and probably this cop should ignore bang methods

Support for allowing bang methods (`AllowBangMethods: true`) was added in #14270.

> Is this prevalent and diverse enough that using `AllowedMethods`/`AllowedPatterns` won't work for your use case?

Well, IDK for now, I'll experiment with it. But the intuition says that it doesn't depend on the method's name, but on its implementation. So the list of allowed names/patterns might grew indefinitely if it is the only way to tell Rubocop "no, that should not be a predicate."

> I don't see why this shouldn't be a predicate method, since it's returning a pretty straightforward check (does the complicated method return :success, the side effects in the method are not relevant IMO).

This really depends on the side effects. (But in general, if the method _has_ significant side effects, it isn't a predicate in my book.)

For a bit less abstract example, a pattern I saw in several codebases was returning booleans from action methods to know if the next action should be done. Like, the main code might do something like this:

```ruby
save_user and update_stripe_account and send_emails
```
I.e., `save_user` might return `false` if the user was invalid (and it also updated the user's `valid?`/`errors`, so the controller that invoked this code might redraw the form and highlight the errors). Then `update_stripe_account` might return `false` if Stripe API returned some error (and again, it might've been saved in some other object to show in UI), and so on.

Whether those methods should be named `save_user?`/`update_stripe_account?` is up to the developer's/team's opinion. For me, they definitely should not. For me, a predicate is an idempotent method that just answers a question about the object's properties, not does something, and returns if it was done successfully.

And returning to `AllowedMethods`/`AllowedPatterns` question, it even might be so that in one context, `save_user` does what I have described, and in other context (or maybe even in this very class!), `save_user?` is a predicate that answers "should we save the user"?
I've disabled this cop for false positives and no discernible benefit in any of my projects. I'm posting this to remind people that's an option.

> I've disabled this cop for false positives and no discernible benefit in any of my projects. I'm posting this to remind people that's an option.

This is true. 

For our project, though, the cop is not useless (to say the least). 

We have maybe a "usual" case of an old codebase that'd lived for many years and is updated "as best as we can", with many small irritating things remaining unnoticed. 

A new, well-defined cop is usually tremendously helpful for some "face-lifting." This one is exactly the case: in our codebase, it was triggered on many small methods in rarely used corners, that "everybody probably agrees should be a predicate, but it was already this way when we came" (and in our policies, "Rubocop is triggered" is a good case for small refactorings). 

It was also triggered by methods with genuinely weird signatures (which returned booleans, and thus Rubocop wanted them to be predicates, but actually nobody needed the booleans they returned, so it is the signature that should be fixed). But also, on methods I describe in original tickets, where only inline `disable`s help :)

That's why I spend some time discussing it: for us, it is tremendously helpful, just in this helpfulness something is amiss :)

Could an option be added to only run one aspect of the cop? It currently does two things:

1. Methods that return a boolean should end in a question mark.
2. Methods that don't return a boolean shouldn't end in a question mark.

From both this discussion and internal discussion after running this cop on some of our projects, it seems (2) is far less controversial than (1). It would be nice to allow the cop to only check (2) and ignore (1).

issueDTO.title: Update deprecated kustomize API version from v1alpha1 to v1
issueDTO.description:
## Description

The kustomize component configuration file uses the deprecated API version `v1alpha1` which should be updated to the stable `v1` API to avoid warnings with kubectl version 1.27 or higher.

## File affected
`jupyter/pytorch/ubi9-python-3.12/kustomize/components/accelerator/kustomization.yaml`

## Required change
```diff
-apiVersion: kustomize.config.k8s.io/v1alpha1
+apiVersion: kustomize.config.k8s.io/v1
```

## Background
This issue was identified during code review and deferred for later implementation to avoid scope creep in the current PR.

## References
- PR: https://github.com/opendatahub-io/notebooks/pull/1230
- Comment: https://github.com/opendatahub-io/notebooks/pull/1230#discussion_r2175221335
- Requested by: @jiridanek

issueDTO.title: View crashed Pod logs (previous logs)
issueDTO.description:
When I am troubleshooting a Pod that has crashed or restarted, I want to be able to view the logs from its previous container instance, so I can understand what caused the failure and take corrective action.


With kubectl you can see the logs for a crashed Pod like this:

```shell
kubectl logs <pod-name> --previous
kubectl logs <pod-name> -c <container-name> --previous
```

API:
```
GET /api/v1/namespaces/{namespace}/pods/{pod}/log?previous=true
```

`previous=true`: fetches logs from the previous container instance, which is useful when the container has crashed or restarted.


We need to design and agree a UI before implementation:
- Maybe an option on the log viewer page?
- Or a separate action "View previous logs" button?



## Additional context

See:
- kubectl logs command reference: https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/kubectl/generated/kubectl_logs/
- Debugging running or crashing pods: https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/debug/debug-application/debug-running-pod/
- Logging architecture overview (includes --previous usage): https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/cluster-administration/logging/
- For example yaml to make a Pod terminate "termination-demo" https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/debug/debug-application/determine-reason-pod-failure/

This was one of the most requested features in dashboard: https://github.com/kubernetes/dashboard/issues/1393 https://github.com/kubernetes/dashboard/pull/2392/files and is a commonly used feature of kubectl.

issueDTO.title: ??? MLIR - Conversion from/to CUDA-Q's `quake` dialect
issueDTO.description:
### What's the problem this feature will solve?

Our efforts in adopting MLIR within the MQT have been steadily progressing.
#880 is the first PR that adds interoperability with an external framework, namely Xanadu's Catalyst and their `Quantum` dialect.
To connect the ecosystem further and to extend the compatibility of the MQT, this issue aims to add support for NVIDIA's `quake` dialect that is used within CUDA-Q. See https://github.com/NVIDIA/cuda-quantum/blob/main/Overview.md for a brief overview.

### Describe the solution you'd like

Similarly to the solution currently being pursued in #880, it should be possible to translate MLIR programs using the Quake dialect to our internal `mqtopt` or `mqtdyn` (see comment below for more details) dialect and back.
The conversion itself can probably borrow quite a few of the implementation details from #880.
The intriguing aspect is the packaging aspect in the sense that it is still an open question how to best add these translations without adding an unconditional dependency on cuda-q. Ideally, the integration is set up similar to how we currently handle Qiskit as an optional plugin of the mqt-core Python package: https://github.com/munich-quantum-toolkit/core/tree/main/src/mqt/core/plugins/qiskit
comments:
We currently have two MLIR dialects: `mqtopt` and `mqtdyn`. 
`mqtopt` uses value semantics, i.e. each operation "consumes" a quantum state and returns an updated state.
`mqtdyn` uses memory semantics. Here, each operation is performed on a reference to a qubit, similar to e.g. OpenQASM's `x q[0]`.

As Quake supports memory semantics (`!quake.ref`) *and* value semantics (`!quake.wire`), this makes conversions a bit more complex. We would rather not have a mix between `mqtopt` and `mqtdyn`, so the Quake operations should be converted to only one of the two dialects. I can see both of them making sense:

- *Convert to `mqtdyn`*: `!quake.ref` operations can be converted directly to `mqtdyn` qubits. For `!quake.wire` operations, search the reference it was originally pulled from through the `quake.unwrap` operation and use that information to translate the wire into a `mqtdyn` qubit.
- *Convert to `mqtopt`*: `!quake.wire` operations can be converted directly to `mqtopt` qubits and their corresponding `quake.wrap`/`quake.unwrap` calls roughly align with `mqtopt.extractQubit` and `mqtopt.insertQubit` calls. For `!quake.ref` operations, `mqtopt` qubits can be extracted from a register using `mqtopt.extractQubit`. Here, we have to keep track in detail what qubit comes from what `mqtopt`-register-index and from what `quake.ref` to make sure different operations do not interfere with each other.

Both approaches seem reasonable, but the first one (converting to `mqtdyn`) seems a bit simpler and may therefore be the better solution, intuitively.

repository.description: MQT Core - The Backbone of the Munich Quantum Toolkit
repository.name: core

summary.main: The main goal of this issue is to add support for NVIDIA's `quake` dialect within the Munich Quantum Toolkit, enabling interoperability with CUDA-Q and extending the compatibility of the MQT.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The issue requires a solution that translates MLIR programs to and from the `quake` dialect, possibly borrowing implementation details from #880. The solution should not add an unconditional dependency on cuda-q.
summary.attemptedFixes: The comments mention two possible approaches: converting to `mqtdyn` and converting to `mqtopt`. The first approach seems simpler and may be the better solution.
summary.otherNotes: The issue aims to add support for NVIDIA's `quake` dialect used within CUDA-Q, allowing for translation of MLIR programs to and from the `quake` dialect, possibly borrowing implementation details from #880. The conversion is complex due to `quake` supporting both memory and value semantics, and the solution will likely involve converting `quake` operations to either `mqtopt` or `mqtdyn` dialect.

issueDTO.title: Phone component
issueDTO.description:
Add a utility component for rendering phone numbers with formatting as an 'a' tag
For example:
998993303030
Would become:
+998(99)330-30-30
comments: @claude Propose an implementation plan

**Claude finished @diyor28's task** ?????? [View job](https://github.com/iota-uz/iota-sdk/actions/runs/16048039555) --- ### Phone Component Implementation Plan **Todo List:** - [x] Analyze current codebase structure and existing components - [x] Understand templ component patterns and organization - [x] Propose phone component implementation plan ## Analysis Results After analyzing the codebase, I found that **extensive phone number infrastructure already exists**: ### Existing Phone Infrastructure - **Phone Value Object**: `/modules/core/domain/value_objects/phone/phone.go` with E.164 conversion, validation, and country detection - **Country Code Mapping**: 254+ countries supported with area codes - **Input Components**: Tel input field and React phone input component - **Database Integration**: Phone fields throughout CRM, HRM, and Core modules ### Gap Identified The codebase **lacks display formatting utilities** - phone numbers are currently shown as raw E.164 strings (`+998993303030`) instead of user-friendly formatted display (`+998(99)330-30-30`). ## Implementation Plan ### 1. **Phone Display Formatting Utility** **Location**: `/modules/core/domain/value_objects/phone/formatter.go` **Functions to Add**: ```go // FormatForDisplay formats phone number for human-readable display func FormatForDisplay(phone Phone) string // FormatWithStyle formats phone number with specific style func FormatWithStyle(phone Phone, style DisplayStyle) string // DisplayStyle constants for different formatting styles type DisplayStyle int const ( StyleParentheses DisplayStyle = iota // +998(99)330-30-30 StyleDashes // +998-99-330-30-30 StyleSpaces // +998 99 330 30 30 ) ``` **Pattern Support**: - **Uzbekistan**: `+998(99)330-30-30` - **US**: `+1(555)123-4567` - **International**: `+44 20 7946 0958` - **Fallback**: Default spacing pattern for unsupported countries ### 2. **Templ Phone Component** **Location**: `/components/base/phone/phone.templ` **Component Structure**: ```go type Props struct { Phone string // Raw phone number Class string // CSS classes Style DisplayStyle // Formatting style ShowIcon bool // Show phone icon Attrs templ.Attributes } templ Link(props Props) { if props.ShowIcon { @icons.Phone(icons.Props{Size: "16"}) } { formatPhoneForDisplay(props.Phone, props.Style) } } ``` ### 3. **Component Integration** **Usage Example**: ```go // In templates @phone.Link(phone.Props{ Phone: client.Phone, Class: "text-blue-600 hover:underline", Style: phone.StyleParentheses, ShowIcon: true, }) ``` ### 4. **Files to Create/Modify** **New Files**: - `/modules/core/domain/value_objects/phone/formatter.go` - Display formatting logic - `/modules/core/domain/value_objects/phone/formatter_test.go` - Test coverage - `/components/base/phone/phone.templ` - Phone display component - `/components/base/phone/phone_templ.go` - Generated templ file **Modified Files**: - Update existing templates to use the new phone component - Add phone component to component registry if needed ### 5. **Testing Strategy** - **Unit Tests**: Format validation for different countries - **Integration Tests**: Component rendering with various props - **Template Tests**: Verify anchor tag generation and tel: links ### 6. **Benefits** - **Leverages Existing Infrastructure**: Uses current phone value object and country detection - **Consistent Formatting**: Centralized formatting logic across all templates - **Accessibility**: Proper tel: links for mobile devices - **Extensible**: Easy to add new formatting styles - **Type Safe**: Follows Go and templ best practices This implementation provides a complete phone display component that transforms raw phone numbers into user-friendly, clickable links while maintaining the existing robust phone number infrastructure. **Implementation Status**: ??? **Plan Complete** - Ready for development

issueDTO.title: [ENH] Type hints for primitives and string arguments
issueDTO.description:
### Describe the feature or idea you want to propose

we would like to increase the use of type hints, and a good first issue is to add them for the simplest case when arguments are primitives (int, float, bool) or strings. Pick a package, look through the code and add type hints. Just for primitives for now, more complex types need a bit of thought. Many have npt.ArrayLike types, but we have not decided on standardising on that, so leave these alone. Dont feel you have to do them all, this is a good first issue to get you started. 

### Describe your proposed solution

for example, the constructor for the anomaly detection algorithm STRAY has these type hints

```
    def __init__(
        self,
        alpha: float = 0.01,
        k: int = 10,
        knn_algorithm: str = "brute",
        p: float = 0.5,
        size_threshold: int = 50,
        outlier_tail: str = "max",
    ):
 ```
but the segmentation algorithm CLASP does not

```
def _is_trivial_match(candidate, change_points, n_timepoints, exclusion_radius=0.05):
    """Check if a candidate change point is in close proximity to other change points.
```



### Describe alternatives you've considered, if relevant

_No response_

### Additional context

_No response_

issueDTO.title: Command distribution retry interval needs to be configurable
issueDTO.description:
Command distribution is automatically retried in case it is not acknowledged in time. The interval between retries uses exponential backoff with hardcoded values. This makes incident response in cases where retry is looping very tricky because there's no way to disable the retry or make it at least slower.

`CommandRedistributor` should not use hardcoded values for `COMMAND_REDISTRIBUTION_INTERVAL` and `RETRY_MAX_BACKOFF_DURATION`. It should be configurable.

This came up in https://app.incident.io/camunda/incidents/2032.
comments: I thinking to bring this to @camunda/core-features-alpha mob-programming session. It is still useful to have configurable retry interval and backoff along with pausing the distribution. E.g. fine tuning re-distribution, allowing engine to slowly make progress without completely stopping the re-distribution or prevent immediate overload after resuming the re-distribution.

repository.description: Process Orchestration Framework
repository.name: camunda

summary.main: Command distribution retry interval needs to be configurable to make incident response easier and allow for fine tuning re-distribution, pausing the distribution, and preventing immediate overload after resuming the re-distribution.
summary.validationOrRequirement: CommandRedistributor should not use hardcoded values for COMMAND_REDISTRIBUTION_INTERVAL and RETRY_MAX_BACKOFF_DURATION. It should be configurable.

summary.otherNotes: This came up in https://app.incident.io/camunda/incidents/2032.

issueDTO.title: feat: add SHA-512 hash support for SBOM formats (CycloneDX and SPDX)
issueDTO.description:
## Description

This is a feature request to add SHA-512 hash algorithm support to Trivy's SBOM parsing capabilities. Currently, Trivy only supports SHA-1, SHA-256, and MD5 hash algorithms when processing SBOM files.

Some tools, particularly NPM's SBOM generation (`npm sbom`), use SHA-512 hashes for package integrity verification. Adding SHA-512 support would enable Trivy to fully process these SBOMs and preserve important security metadata.

### Current limitations:
- **CycloneDX**: SHA-512 hashes are ignored and the hashes field becomes `null`
- **SPDX**: SHA-512 checksums are completely omitted from the output


## Current Behavior

### CycloneDX
In `pkg/sbom/cyclonedx/unmarshal.go:251-268`, the `unmarshalHashes` function only supports:
- SHA1
- SHA256
- MD5

Any other algorithm (including SHA-512) logs a warning but still creates a digest with an empty algorithm prefix (e.g., `:hashvalue` instead of `sha512:hashvalue`), resulting in malformed digest strings.

### SPDX
In `pkg/sbom/spdx/marshal.go:501-522`, the `spdxChecksums` function has the same limitation, returning `nil` for unsupported algorithms.

## Root Cause

The limitation stems from `pkg/digest/digest.go` which only defines three algorithms:
```go
const (
    SHA1   Algorithm = "sha1"
    SHA256 Algorithm = "sha256"
    MD5    Algorithm = "md5"
)
```

## Desired Behavior

Trivy should support SHA-512 hash algorithm alongside the existing SHA-1, SHA-256, and MD5 support. This would enable Trivy to:
- Preserve SHA-512 hashes when processing SBOMs from NPM and other tools
- Generate SBOMs with SHA-512 hashes when appropriate
- Maintain full compatibility with CycloneDX and SPDX specifications


## Impact

- Loss of package integrity verification data
- Generated SBOMs may be invalid or incomplete
- Affects tools that rely on SHA-512 for security validation

## Proposed Solution

1. Add SHA512 constant to `pkg/digest/digest.go`:
   ```go
   const (
       SHA1   Algorithm = "sha1"
       SHA256 Algorithm = "sha256"
       SHA512 Algorithm = "sha512"
       MD5    Algorithm = "md5"
   )
   ```

2. Add SHA-512 calculation support in the digest package

3. Update `unmarshalHashes` in CycloneDX:
   ```go
   case cdx.HashAlgoSHA512:
       alg = digest.SHA512
   ```

4. Update `spdxChecksums` in SPDX:
   ```go
   case digest.SHA512:
       alg = spdx.SHA512
   ```

## References

- NPM SBOM documentation: https://docs.npmjs.com/cli/v10/commands/npm-sbom
- CycloneDX hash algorithm specification: https://cyclonedx.org/docs/1.6/json/#components_items_hashes
- SPDX checksum specification: https://spdx.github.io/spdx-spec/v2.3/package-information/#79-package-checksum-field

## Test Data

### CycloneDX Example
```json
{
  "$schema": "http://cyclonedx.org/schema/bom-1.5.schema.json",
  "bomFormat": "CycloneDX",
  "specVersion": "1.5",
  "components": [
    {
      "bom-ref": "lodash@4.17.21",
      "type": "library",
      "name": "lodash",
      "version": "4.17.21",
      "hashes": [
        {
          "alg": "SHA-512",
          "content": "bf690311ee7b95e713ba568322e3533f2dd1cb880b189e99d4edef13592b81764daec43e2c54c61d5c558dc5cfb35ecb85b65519e74026ff17675b6f8f916f4a"
        }
      ]
    }
  ]
}
```

### SPDX Example
```json
{
  "spdxVersion": "SPDX-2.3",
  "packages": [
    {
      "name": "lodash",
      "SPDXID": "SPDXRef-Package-lodash-4.17.21",
      "checksums": [
        {
          "algorithm": "SHA512",
          "checksumValue": "bf690311ee7b95e713ba568322e3533f2dd1cb880b189e99d4edef13592b81764daec43e2c54c61d5c558dc5cfb35ecb85b65519e74026ff17675b6f8f916f4a"
        }
      ]
    }
  ]
}
```

### Discussed in https://github.com/aquasecurity/trivy/discussions/9082
comments:

However, since we want to include it in the next release, if you cannot make it this month, we may ask someone else to take care of it.

summary.otherNotes: This is a feature request to add SHA-512 hash algorithm support to Trivy's SBOM parsing capabilities. Currently, Trivy only supports SHA-1, SHA-256, and MD5 hash algorithms when processing SBOM files. Adding SHA-512 support would enable Trivy to fully process these SBOMs and preserve important security metadata.

issueDTO.title: Simplify test code where a dataset is set as gated

[huggingface_hub@0.25.0](https://github.com/huggingface/huggingface_hub/releases/tag/v0.25.0) provides an API to set a repository as gated.

We had included a custom version of `update_repo_settings` because it lacked a `gated` parameter. Now we can switch back to the `huggingface_hub` method

https://github.com/huggingface/dataset-viewer/blob/4859100ef282dcf73257dfb60e6b5a20d5955c68/jobs/cache_maintenance/tests/utils.py#L41
https://github.com/huggingface/dataset-viewer/blob/4859100ef282dcf73257dfb60e6b5a20d5955c68/services/admin/tests/fixtures/hub.py#L24
https://github.com/huggingface/dataset-viewer/blob/4859100ef282dcf73257dfb60e6b5a20d5955c68/services/worker/tests/fixtures/hub.py#L35
comments: depends on https://github.com/huggingface/dataset-viewer/issues/3064

Hi @severo ??? I???d like to pick this up.

Now that `huggingface_hub>=0.25.0` supports the `gated` parameter in `HfApi.update_repo_settings`, I???ll remove the custom implementations in the following test files:

- `jobs/cache_maintenance/tests/utils.py`
- `services/admin/tests/fixtures/hub.py`
- `services/worker/tests/fixtures/hub.py`

Each call to `update_repo_settings(...)` will be replaced with the official method, and the custom functions will be removed. Let me know if that sounds good!
good idea

> good idea

Just opened a new PR! #3206

issueDTO.title: Instant meeting outside of dashboard?
issueDTO.description:
<!--- Please keep this note for other contributors -->

### How to use GitHub

* Please use the 👍 [reaction](https://blog.github.com/2016-03-10-add-reactions-to-pull-requests-issues-and-comments/) to show that you are interested into the same feature.
* Please don't comment if you have no relevant information to add. It's just extra noise for everyone subscribed to this issue.
* Subscribe to receive notifications on status change and new comments.

---

## Feature request

Maybe this was already discussed during the dashboard design, but I couldn't find it.

With the new dashboard we have now "Start meeting", which allows us to create an "instant meeting", that is automatically deleted after 1 day by default. This option is _only_ available on the dashboard. So to start an instant meeting while in a conversation, one first has to drop to the dashboard to then create the meeting. (and understand, that the option is only there)

I think we should consider adding this option to the "add" menu as well, so it is reachable even outside the dashboard.

issueDTO.title: Airflow Databricks Operator Task Group Launch Task Not Properly Waiting for Upstream Tasks
issueDTO.description: ### Apache Airflow Provider(s) databricks ### Versions of Apache Airflow Providers 7.3.2 ### Apache Airflow version 2.10.3 ### Operating System managed airflow ### Deployment Docker-Compose ### Deployment details _No response_ ### What happened When using DatabricksWorkflowTaskGroups, a launch task is created. This launch task can be set to have upstream dependencies, however no matter what the launch task will not wait on any dependencies to execute, executing as soon as the dag run starts. This keeps us from using any parameters defined as part of a task that is intended to run before the task group initializes, for example setting parameters in the task group definition. ### What you think should happen instead This task should instead wait on prior tasks to finish as aligned with the trigger_rule assigned to that specific task. As the trigger_rule by default for the launch task is set to all_success, the task should NOT run until all upstream dependencies have finished. ### How to reproduce ```from airflow.models import DAG from airflow.operators.dummy import DummyOperator from airflow.providers.databricks.operators.databricks_workflow import ( DatabricksWorkflowTaskGroup, ) with DAG( dag_id="example_dag", schedule_interval=f"0 0 * * *", ) as dag: start_task = DummyOperator(task_id="end", trigger_rule="none_failed") task_group = DatabricksWorkflowTaskGroup( group_id="tg", databricks_conn_id="FILL IN DBX CONNECTION ID", job_clusters={ "job_cluster_key": "test_cluster", "new_cluster": { "cluster_name": "", "spark_version": "15.4.x-scala2.12", "node_type_id": "r4.2xlarge", "num_workers": 1, "autoscale": {"min_workers": 2, "max_workers": 8}, "aws_attributes": { "availability": "SPOT_WITH_FALLBACK", "ebs_volume_count": 1, "ebs_volume_size": 100, "ebs_volume_type": "GENERAL_PURPOSE_SSD", "first_on_demand": 1, "spot_bid_price_percent": 100, "zone_id": "auto", }, }, }, ) with task_group: pass ``` ### Anything else _No response_ ### Are you willing to submit PR? - [x] Yes I am willing to submit a PR! ### Code of Conduct - [x] I agree to follow this project's [Code of Conduct](https://github.com/apache/airflow/blob/main/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md)

repository.description: Apache Airflow - A platform to programmatically author, schedule, and monitor workflows
repository.name: airflow

summary.main: Airflow Databricks Operator Task Group Launch Task should wait for upstream tasks to finish, as per the trigger_rule assigned to that specific task, rather than executing as soon as the dag run starts.
summary.validationOrRequirement: Validation or requirement is not explicitly mentioned in the issue description
summary.attemptedFixes: No specific attempted fixes mentioned in the issue description
summary.otherNotes: The issue is related to Airflow Databricks Operator Task Group Launch Task not properly waiting for upstream tasks, which prevents using parameters defined in task group definition. It also includes a code snippet for reproduction.

issueDTO.title: [MCP] Pinterest
issueDTO.description:
## 🧩 Product Overview  

Pinterest is a visual discovery engine for finding ideas like recipes, home and style inspiration, and more.
This integration allows AI agents and workflows to create, manage, and interact with Pins and Boards, automating content sharing and curation.

---

## ?????? Important Note for Contributors  

To ensure consistency and maintainability, this feature must be submitted as a [Piece](https://www.activepieces.com/docs/developers/building-pieces/piece-definition) following the Activepieces architecture. Submissions that do not follow this format will not be accepted. Please make sure to review the [Piece Development Guidelines](https://www.activepieces.com/docs/developers/building-pieces/overview) before starting development.

---

## 🚨 Triggers  

| **Trigger** | **Use Case** |
|:--------------------------|:---------------------------------------|
| **New Pin on Board** | Fires when a new Pin is added to a specific board.|
|**New Follower**| Triggers when a user gains a new follower.|
|**New Board**| Fires when a new board is created in the account.|

---

## 🛠??? Write Actions   

| **Action Item**               | **Use Case**                                                                                                                                     |
|:------------------------------|:-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| **Create Pin** | Upload an image or video to create a new Pin on a board.|
|**Create Board**|Create a new Pinterest board for organizing Pins.|
|**Update Board**| Modify a board???s name, description, or visibility settings.|
|**Delete Pin**| Permanently delete a specific Pin. |

---

## 🔍 Search Actions

| **Trigger** | **Use Case** |
|:--------------------------|:---------------------------------------|
| **Find Pin by Title/Keyword** | Search for Pins using a title, description, or tag.|
|**Find Board by Name**| Locate a board by its name for pinning or updates.|

---

## 📚 API Reference  
- [Official Pinterest API Documentation](https://developers.pinterest.com/docs/api/v5/)

---

## 🧪 Test Account Access  
You can test Pinterest APIs by registering your app on the [Pinterest Developers Portal](https://developers.pinterest.com/)  and generating OAuth tokens.


---

## 🧑???💻 New to Activepieces?

Activepieces is the leading open source AI automation platform. We have many apps (we call them Pieces), that are available within the builder and as MCPs. These apps are built with our TypeScript framework and are easy to develop. Once merged into our repository, they become available as pieces in our automation builder and as MCPs usable by AI agents and MCP clients.

Start building here: [Piece Development Docs](https://www.activepieces.com/docs/developers/building-pieces/overview)

issueDTO.title: Title: Error When Using Multiple DataSets as Triggers in Apache AirFlow
issueDTO.description:
### Apache Airflow version

2.8.0

### If "Other Airflow 2 version" selected, which one?

_No response_

### What happened?

When using two or more DataSets as triggers, an error occurs while accessing the `source_task_instance` object of `DatasetEvent`.

### What you think should happen instead?

It should be possible to access all fields of every `DatasetEvent`.

### How to reproduce

Create two test DAGs (producer and consumer) and link them with two DataSets.
Code:
```python
from __future__ import annotations

from datetime import datetime

from airflow.datasets import Dataset
from airflow.decorators import task, dag

testDataSet = Dataset('/test')
testDataSet2 = Dataset('/test2')


@dag(
    dag_id='dag_producer',
    schedule=None,
    start_date=datetime(2021, 1, 1),
    catchup=False,
)
def dag_producer():
    @task(outlets=[testDataSet, testDataSet2])
    def test():
        return 'OK'

    test()


@dag(
    dag_id="dag_consumer",
    schedule=[testDataSet, testDataSet2],
    start_date=datetime(2021, 1, 1),
    catchup=False,

)
def dag_consumer():
    @task
    def print_triggering_dataset_events(triggering_dataset_events=None):
        for dataset, dataset_list in triggering_dataset_events.items():
            for dataset_event in dataset_list:
                print('Task result: ', dataset_event.source_task_instance.xcom_pull(task_ids='test'))

    print_triggering_dataset_events()


dag_consumer()
dag_producer()
```

### Operating System

Debian GNU/Linux 12 (bookworm)

### Versions of Apache Airflow Providers
```

```

### Deployment

Docker-Compose

repository.name: airflow

summary.main: The main goal of the issue is to resolve the error when using multiple DataSets as triggers in Apache Airflow and accessing the `source_task_instance` object of `DatasetEvent`.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The issue seems to be related to the way Airflow handles sessions and lazy loading. The requirement is to be able to access the `source_task_instance` object of `DatasetEvent` when using multiple DataSets as triggers.
summary.attemptedFixes: The issue has been observed to occur when using S3Hook and fetching data from Connection in the metadata database. However, retrieving data from environment variables seems to work as a workaround. Another workaround is to manually create a session and use it to access the `source_task_instance` object.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is about accessing the `source_task_instance` object of `DatasetEvent` when using two or more DataSets as triggers in Apache Airflow. The problem is that the `source_task_instance` is not bound to a Session, causing a lazy load operation to fail.

issueDTO.title: Add concepts from ENISA SotA Tech/Org Measures
issueDTO.description:
ENISA has published a Guideline on State of the art for Technical and Organisational measures. Georg/Signatu have proposed these be integrated into DPV's TOMs concepts - see [email with attached document](https://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-dpvcg/2023Nov/0002.html).

1. [harsh's reply](https://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-dpvcg/2023Nov/0007.html) with overview analysis of document and proposals for concepts in TOMs, RISK, and standards sections.
2. https://www.enisa.europa.eu/topics/cybersecurity-policy/nis-directive-new/minimum-security-measures-for-operators-of-essentials-services - tool showing mapping between measures from ISO 27001, NIST CSF, and ISA/IEC 62443
3. https://www.enisa.europa.eu/topics/cybersecurity-policy/nis-directive-new - measures for NIS2 directive implementations
comments:
The attached document details the 48 NIS2V Terms, where there was no match to DPV. 
These are from both the ISO27001 controls and the ENISA Minimum Security Measures for Operators of Essentials Services.
Any questions, please let me know.

[NIS2V Terms - Jenni Parry.xlsx](https://github.com/w3c/dpv/files/15232754/NIS2V.Terms.-.Jenni.Parry.xlsx)
@Jenni0608 thanks for sharing. Would `dpv:Policy` be a broad match for something like Policy on risk etc. in these terms?

Maybe for two of them (Control 5.1 & A.5.4) but looking at the definitions its nearly too broad: DPV Policy Definition - A guidance document outlining any of: procedures, plans, principles, decisions, intent, or protocols.
Versus control: Management shall require all personnel to apply information security in accordance with the established information security policy, topic-specific policies and procedures of the organisation.

Maybe that's because DPV doesn't model _controls_ but the _concept_ representing the control (more accurately the information) e.g. procedure to apply/enforce policy vs policy itself? If so, then the matching process should check/include the concept for information, and state that it doesn't accurately reflect the intended control i.e. an action or procedure?

repository.name: dpv

summary.main: Integrate ENISA SotA Tech/Org Measures into DPV's TOMs concepts
summary.validationOrRequirement: DPV Policy Definition - A guidance document outlining any of: procedures, plans, principles, decisions, intent, or protocols. Versus control: Management shall require all personnel to apply information security in accordance with the established information security policy, topic-specific policies and procedures of the organisation.
summary.attemptedFixes: The matching process should check/include the concept for information, and state that it doesn't accurately reflect the intended control i.e. an action or procedure?
summary.otherNotes: ENISA has published a Guideline on State of the art for Technical and Organisational measures. Georg/Signatu have proposed these be integrated into DPV's TOMs concepts. The attached document details the 48 NIS2V Terms, where there was no match to DPV. Any questions, please let me know.

issueDTO.title: [docs-bug]: Navigation buttons out of logical order on documentation pages
issueDTO.description:
### Problem: What is happening?

Currently, the navigation buttons in the "Projects" section of the documentation are not following a logical sequence.
For example, at the end of the ???Add a Project??? page, the "Next" button does not follow the expected reading flow for this section.
Ideally, after learning how to create a project, the user should be directed to the ???View Project??? page, continuing the logical progression of the process.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/ce37121d-8d7e-42e5-938d-376682f04cd3)


### Expected behavior

The ???Next??? button should lead to the page ???View a project???



The same issue occurs on the ???List Projects??? page, where the recommended setup would be to organize the navigation buttons as follows, respecting a logical reading sequence:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/8540b274-432f-4b9d-9965-fb8736db2112)


On the ???View a Project??? page, the "Next" button could direct the user to the ???Add an Environment??? section.
This transition makes sense within the platform's logic, as after creating and viewing a project, the natural next step is to configure an environment within it.
This way, the user understands that they can now start structuring the resources and services related to that project, maintaining a continuous and intuitive workflow.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/b05753cd-b5cf-4fab-b1ae-cdb187c820f9)

### Steps to reproduce

1 - Access the documentation at:
devopness.com/docs

2 - Navigate to the following section:
projects/add-project

3 - Make sure the "Previous" and "Next" navigation buttons follow the logical reading order.

📌 Suggestion summary:
Fix the navigation button links in the Projects section so they follow the logical reading flow of the section.



### Which Devopness module(s) are the source of the bug?

Documentation

### Package Version

_No response_

### Reproduction link

_No response_

### Additional details

_No response_

issueDTO.title: [Bug]: Email verification input text field should not be multiline on login screen
issueDTO.description:
### Summary

At the login screen, sometimes we need to enter a verification code received by email, likely when we sign up on a new device. This email verification input field appears after providing the correct username and password. 

### Steps to reproduce

1. Freshly install the Commons App
2. Open the app and try to log in with your username and password
3. An email verification input field should appear
4. Make sure email verification input field is focused
5. Tap on the `Enter` button in the software keyboard of Android

### Expected behaviour

The **IME Action** for the email verification input field should be either `Done` or `Go`. Also, the input field's height shouldn't increase when pressing the `Enter` button.

### Actual behaviour

The `Enter` **IME Action** is displayed in the Android's soft keyboard, and tapping that increases the input field's height.

Pixel 6

Android 14

Main Branch

_No response_

issueDTO.title: [RFE]: Provide dev contribution guide for Mac OS system
issueDTO.description:
## Current situation
Mac OS runs zsh and the makefile of the project fails to execute certain commands on MAC Os.
Ex: `cd backend && ./tools/check_pkg_test.sh`
One can try to apply some hacks over the file to run the project manually.
But if option comes from upstream it will be something trustworthy.
Makefile of the project acc

## Impact

MAC Os users will be able to contribute.
comments:
I was trying to set up development environment by following the [guide](https://kinvolk.io/docs/nebraska/latest/development/)
on Mac Os Intel System.

Running Node JS: 10/12 (Tried on Both)

1. Issues in smoothly executing Makefile.
2.  `make run-backend`  fails with ```lags "-static"" -o bin/nebraska ./cmd/nebraska
./bin/nebraska -auth-mode noop
make: ./bin/nebraska: No such file or directory``` , I made my workaround over this by manually running this file and able to start the server.
3. `make run-frontend` executes and starts the server  but getting CORS ``` Error: A cross-origin error was thrown. React doesn't have access to the actual error object in development. See https://fb.me/react-crossorigin-error for more information.``` . I am not sure if this is happening because of something specific to OS.

4. On executing `check_pkg_test.sh` : mapfile: command not found
Not sure if this project is meant to support development on MAC OS. If that's not the case then we can close the issue.

Update on Testing with on Fedora:

1. No issues in make run-backend for the first run. (As expected cause Fedora runs Bash)
2. make run-frontend . (No issues again on the command) But still facing 
```
CORS Error: A cross-origin error was thrown. React doesn't have access to the actual error object in development. See https://fb.me/react-crossorigin-error for more information.
```
had similar issue running `make` (very first step) on mac m1. Has this been resolved?
@ervcz This is still valid and could probably use some work if we wanted to throw a `help-wanted` tag on this.

Hi! I've tried to analyze the macOS compatibility issues in the Nebraska development scripts and I would like to point out thefollowing potential problems:

1. **Bash version incompatibility**:
  - `backend/tools/check_pkg_test.sh` uses `mapfile` (line 11), which was introduced in bash 4.0
  - [macOS ships with bash 3.2 because they have licensing problems](https://discussions.apple.com/thread/255353799?answerId=259964001022&sortBy=rank#259964001022)

2. **GNU vs BSD utilities**:
  - `backend/tools/setup_local_db.sh` and `backend/tools/run-all.sh` use GNU getopt with `--longoptions`
  - macOS ships with BSD getopt which doesn't support long options like `--longoptions`
  - This is a fundamental difference between BSD and GNU implementations

3. **There might be other similar compatibility issues, e.g. in**:
  - backend/tools/run-all.sh - uses GNU getopt with long options and bash arrays

### Potential fix for check_pkg_test.sh

Replace lines 10-11:
```bash
output_lines=()
mapfile -t output_lines < <(go list -f '{{.Dir}} - {{.TestGoFiles}} {{.XTestGoFiles}}' ./...)
```

With this bash 3.2 compatible version:
```bash
output_lines=()
while IFS= read -r line; do
    output_lines+=("$line")
done < <(go list -f '{{.Dir}} - {{.TestGoFiles}} {{.XTestGoFiles}}' ./...)
```

### Workaround for GNU Utilities

Install GNU versions via Homebrew:
brew install coreutils gnu-getopt

### Add to ~/.zshrc or ~/.bash_profile:
export PATH="/usr/local/opt/coreutils/libexec/gnubin:$PATH"
export PATH="/usr/local/opt/gnu-getopt/bin:$PATH"

### Testing Help Needed

I don't have access to macOS to test these changes. Could someone please:

1. Test if the modified check_pkg_test.sh works with the change above
2. Verify if the GNU utilities installation resolves issues with other scripts
3. Try running make and make run-backend after installing dependencies (the gnu utility, docker etc.)
4. Report any other script failures and their error messages

Once confirmed working, we should create a PR with:
- The script compatibility fix
- Updates to the main README

Any macOS developers willing to help test? 🙏
